comments.commentBody: The plan to reroute some of the many  meanders of the Mississippi was not such a bad idea, but the execution under wartime conditions apparently suffered from insufficiently rigorous surveying. As the piece describes, the river took the most natural reroute on its own in 1876, so success seems to have hinged upon getting that proclivity properly recognized and acted upon.

Br - I disagree. A skeet or trap shotgun is typically quite long, and usually has very low capacity, which would make it not the best choice for home defense use.

Kay - I think training and regular practice are important to gain and retain familiarity and proficiency with one's firearms. I myself do not hunt. But the caliber most often used in an AR15, 5.56mm, is actually one of the least powerful rifle cartridges out there. It is actually illegal to hunt deer with that caliber in many states as the round is considered too weak to be used to humanely harvest deer. For game like deer, elk, and larger, calibers like .30-06,.308, 7mm magnum and others are often used. Some game is hunted at much greater range/distance too, which also requires more powerful calibers. AR15's and AR10's are available in calibers more suited to hunting deer. More hunters are beginning to use the AR for the same reasons I spoke of before.....it is light, accurate, rugged, and versatile. The 5.56mm cartridge may be used for smaller game like coyote, or prairie dogs.

And registration does not necessarily equal confiscation, but it is often the first (and arguably necessary precursor) to confiscation. If you are going to confiscate something, it helps to know where they are.

I am an avid shooter. I respect other people's right to disagree with me on the issue of gun control. I don't really think anyone on either side of the debate is going to convince someone on the opposing side to change their point of view on this matter. I don't try to. I will gladly answer someone's questions about firearms or shooting if they ask, even if they are anti-gun. There is soooo much misinformation about firearms out there, and people who have had little or no exposure to, or education on guns don't know any better. And that lack of familiarity and that misinformation can color their opinions.

The AR15 is one of the most popular rifles in the country. It is not some strange, rare, fringe element weapon. It is a completely modular design that is very well suited to a variety purposes for which a rifle is appropriate including self-defense, hunting, short and long range target shooting, and competition. It is a light, accurate, rugged, and versatile platform. It is not more deadly than any other rifle. The "regular guns" that many gun control proponents feel are acceptable are significantly more powerful.

Lastly, I'll just say that because someone owns a handful of guns does not mean they possess an "arsenal". Guns are tools, and different guns are suited to different uses. A shotgun used for skeet wouldn't be a great choice for a home defense shotgun, and neither would be ideally suited as a hunting shotgun. The same applies to pistols and rifles.

Clairette: As I pointed out in my post below, many people use firearms daily, because they need them as tools.

My firearms are not "scattered" anywhere: they are either secured in my gun safe when not in use (as Mrs. Lanza's should have been), or they are in my pick-up truck when I'm checking on my cattle.

We already pay an 11% Federal excise tax on all firearms, ammunition, and other shooting supplies as provided for by the Pittman-Robertson Act, which funds wildlife and wildlife habitat conservation activities conducted by the fish and game departments of all 50 states.

Further, since my firearms are Constitutionally protected, as is Mr. Sulzberger's printing press, I think you might have a problem with your proposal because, as John Marshall wrote in Marbury v. Madison, "the power to tax involves the power to destroy." Although that decision was limited to forbidding to the States the power to tax financial instruments issued by the Federal government, it has since been applied, in practice, to newspapers (at the level of retail sale) because the freedom of the press is specifically protected by the First Amendment. I do not think I will have too much of a stretch in persuading a Federal court to extend Mr. Marshall's dictum to other Constitutionally-protected inanimate objects, such as my semi-automatic firearms and the ammunition they use.

If you want to pass a sumptuary law, why not start with your $5 lattes? You surely need those far less than I need my AR-15.

The difference is, it is easy to come up with quite a few positives when it comes to automobiles--for instance, I'll accept the risk of driving because it is worth it to take my mother to church, and there is no other practical means of doing so. Or, i accept the risk of driving because I need a way to get to work and there is no other practical means of doing so. There is no parallel when it comes to firearms: The jollies one derives by shooting AR15's on firing ranges outweigh the tragedies and pain of Sandy Hook and Columbine and all the other places. Not hardly. In essence, it's a risk/benefit equation, and I submit that the risks inherent in our current system of regulating firearms far outweigh the benefits.
